profile.note: USDA plant profile pages are JavaScript-rendered. Full data extraction requires browser automation (Selenium/Playwright).

profile_page.note: Full HTML not stored in JSON. Use browser automation for complete data extraction.

plant_guide_pdf.note: PDF content stored separately. Use PDF parsing library to extract structured data.

extracted_data.full_text_excerpt:
Plant Guide
SHOWY MILKWEED fibers over a hard surface. Twisting the fiber
opposite each other and twining them together
Asclepias speciosa Torr. formed the cord; often this was accomplished by
rolling the fibers on the thigh while twisting them
Plant Symbol = ASSP
together.
Contributed By: USDA NRCS National Plant Data Vast quantities of fiber plants are required for the
Center making of nets, regalia, and cordage by California
Indians. Blackburn and Anderson (1993) quote Craig
Bates of the Yosemite Museum that it takes
approximately five stalks of milkweed or Indian
hemp to manufacture one foot of cordage. A Sierra
Miwok feather skirt or cape contain about 100 feet of
cordage made from approximately 500 plant stalks,
while a deer net 40 feet in length contained some
7,000 feet of cordage, which would have required the
harvesting of a staggering 35,000 plant stalks,
(Barrett and Gifford 1933:178).
The young shoots, stems, flower buds, immature
fruits, and roots of showy milkweed were boiled and
eaten as a vegetable by various indigenous groups of
eastern and mid-western America.
JE & Bonnie McClellan
© California Academy of In some areas the young leaves and stems were used
Sciences
as greens. The flowers were also eaten raw or boiled,
@ CalPhotos
and the buds were boiled for soup or with meat. The
most common use for these plants, recorded among
